DataElement.preferredName: Bone Marrow Transplantation Performed FACT Certified Site Ind
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A response used to determine whether a procedure to replace bone marrow that has been destroyed by treatment with high doses of anticancer drugs or radiation has been executed at a site that has been through the process by which a person demonstrates specific knowledge, skills, or abilities in the view of the Foundation for the Accreditation of Cellular Therapy (FACT), a non-profit corporation co-founded by the International Society for Cellular Therapy and the American Society of Blood and Marrow Transplantation for the purposes of voluntary inspection and accreditation in the field of cellular therapy.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Bone Marrow Transplantation Performed Foundation for the Accreditation of Cellular Therapy Certification Site
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A procedure to replace bone marrow that has been destroyed by treatment with high doses of anticancer drugs or radiation. Transplantation may be autologous (an individual's own marrow saved before treatment), allogeneic (marrow donated by someone else), or syngeneic (marrow donated by an identical twin)._Executed and carried through to completion._A non-profit corporation co-founded by the International Society for Cellular Therapy and the American Society of Blood and Marrow Transplantation for the purposes of voluntary inspection and accreditation in the field of cellular therapy. Founded in 1996, FACT establishes standards for high quality medical and laboratory practice in cellular therapies. FACT Standards are evidence-based requirements set by world-renowned experts vested in the improvement and progress of cellular therapy._The process by which a person demonstrates specific knowledge, skills, or abilities in the view of a certifying body.  Similarly, the process by which a product or process can achieve certification indicating its suitability for a specific purpose._A position in relation to its surroundings.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (trans-plan-TAY-shun) A procedure to replace bone marrow destroyed by treatment with high doses of anticancer drugs or radiation. Transplantation may be autologous (an individual's own marrow saved before treatment), allogeneic (marrow donated by someone else), or syngeneic (marrow donated by an identical twin).

Concepts.definition: A procedure to replace diseased bone marrow with transplanted healthy bone marrow cells.

Property.preferredName: Performed Foundation for the Accreditation of Cellular Therapy Certification Site
Property.preferredDefinition: Executed and carried through to completion.:A non-profit corporation co-founded by the International Society for Cellular Therapy and the American Society of Blood and Marrow Transplantation for the purposes of voluntary inspection and accreditation in the field of cellular therapy. Founded in 1996, FACT establishes standards for high quality medical and laboratory practice in cellular therapies. FACT Standards are evidence-based requirements set by world-renowned experts vested in the improvement and progress of cellular therapy.:The process by which a person demonstrates specific knowledge, skills, or abilities in the view of a certifying body.  Similarly, the process by which a product or process can achieve certification indicating its suitability for a specific purpose.:A position in relation to its surroundings.

Concepts.definition: Executed and carried through to completion.

Concepts.longName: Foundation for the Accreditation of Cellular Therapy
Concepts.definition: A non-profit corporation co-founded by the International Society for Cellular Therapy and the American Society of Blood and Marrow Transplantation for the purposes of voluntary inspection and accreditation in the field of cellular therapy. Founded in 1996, FACT establishes standards for high quality medical and laboratory practice in cellular therapies. FACT Standards are evidence-based requirements set by world-renowned experts vested in the improvement and progress of cellular therapy.

The process by which a person demonstrates specific knowledge, skills, or abilities in the view of a certifying body.  Similarly, the process by which a product or process can achieve certification indicating its suitability for a specific purpose.
A position in relation to its surroundings.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.
